title: Effectiveness of shallow temperature surveys to target a geothermal reservoir at previously explored site at McGee Mountain, Nevada: Final Report for U.S. Department Of Energy Grant EE-0002830
name: effectiveness-of-shallow-temperature-surveys-to-target-a-geothermal-reservoir-at-previousl
notes: Effectiveness of shallow temperature surveys to target a geothermal reservoir at previously explored site at McGee Mountain, NevadannFinal Report for U.S. Department Of Energy Grant EE-0002830nnThe McGee Mountain geothermal area was selected for funding under U.S. Department of Energy Grant DE-FOA-0002830 to test early-stage shallow temperature survey techniques and drill two slim holes to test the resource. Geothermal Technical Partners, Inc., the recipient of the grant, was able to complete only a small portion of the project before lack of funding prevented further exploration work. This work included a shallow (2-meter) temperature survey, a Geoprobe survey, a close-spaced gravity survey, and several reports on geologic and transmission viability.nnThe 18-page report includes a description of the geothermal geology of the area, geochemistry and geothermometry of nearby springs and wells, and findings from the shallow temperature survey, Geoprobe survey, close-spaced gravity survey, heat-in-place estimate, transmission viability, and an archeological survey. The report makes the following conclusions:nnBesides further exploring the resource at McGee Mountain, the project did fulfill at least some of its original goals of assessing the effectiveness of the two shallow temperature survey techniques. This assessment was augmented somewhat by including 2-meter and Geoprobe surveys at two other geothermal sites in Nevada. Some of the conclusions reached are as follows:nu2022tBoth the shallow 2-meter and the Geoprobe surveys are cost-effective methods to detect subsurface thermal anomalies in early-stage exploration, prior to more expensive temperature gradient drilling.nu2022tThe major advantages of the 2-meter survey are its extreme portability (no roads needed), cost per site measurement, and low environmental impact.nu2022tThe 2-meter surveyu2019s disadvantages are its inability to penetrate hard substrates and the noise effects due to solar heating of the ground.nu2022tThe Geoprobeu2019s advantages are its ability to collect temperature and uncontaminated water samples, greater depth of penetration (to 60m), relatively low cost, and low environmental impact.nu2022tThe Geoprobeu2019s disadvantages are its inability to go off-road or to penetrate hard substrates.nu2022tCosts to perform both types of surveys are low, together less than the cost of one conventional temperature gradient well. Given the potential increase in data that these surveys can provide, this is extreme value for the exploration dollar.n
